On this page

Sequences

Standard Types (Primatives)

  • numbers
  • strings
  • lists
  • tuples
  • sets
  • dictionaries

Lists

Characteristics

  • flexibile containers (strings only contain alphanumeric characters)
  • heterogeneous elements
  • nestable
  • mutable

Creation

x = ['a', 1, 'b', -8, 7.2]
x


['a', 1, 'b', -8, 7.2]

z = [x, 'a string of words']
z


[['a', 1, 'b', -8, 7.2], 'a string of words']

y = []
y


[]

Slicing

x


['a', 1, 'b', -8, 7.2]

x[2]


'b'

x[1:-1]


[1, 'b', -8]

x[0]


'a'

x[-3:]


['b', -8, 7.2]

Nestable

a = range(4)
b = ['every', 'other', 'word']
c = [a, b]
c


[range(0, 4), ['every', 'other', 'word']]

Mutable

c


[range(0, 4), ['every', 'other', 'word']]

c[0] = 'this is a string'
c


['this is a string', ['every', 'other', 'word']]

c[0][0]


't'

c[0][0] = 'T'



    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

    TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)

    <ipython-input-13-7ab0f3430836> in <module>
    ----> 1 c[0][0] = 'T'
    

    TypeError: 'str' object does not support item assignment

List Operations

a = ['1', 'serge', 1000]


b = a + a
b


['1', 'serge', 1000, '1', 'serge', 1000]

c = a * 4
c


['1',
 'serge',
 1000,
 '1',
 'serge',
 1000,
 '1',
 'serge',
 1000,
 '1',
 'serge',
 1000]

List functions

x = [1, 2, 3, 90]
len(x)


4

max(x)


90

min(x)


1

List methods

y = []
y


[]

y.append(10)
y


[10]

x = [1, 2, 3]
x


[1, 2, 3]

x.append(y)
x


[1, 2, 3, [10]]

x.extend(y)
x


[1, 2, 3, [10], 10]

Note the subtle difference between the two methods. Sometimes you will want to use append, and other times extend is what you need.

Other list methods, sort and reverse:

x = [7, 1, 3, 12]
x


[7, 1, 3, 12]

x.sort()
x


[1, 3, 7, 12]

x.reverse()
x


[12, 7, 3, 1]

Keep in mind that they are in-place methods meaning they modify the object. In other words they don’t return anything, but rather work on the object’s data:

z = x.sort()


z


type(z)


NoneType

If you want to keep the original list as is but get a new list with elements equal to the sorted elements from the first list:

x = [2, 3, 1, 7, 4]
z = sorted(x)


z


[1, 2, 3, 4, 7]

x


[2, 3, 1, 7, 4]

Other useful list methods

x = [1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]
x.count(3)


3

x.count(-8)


0

3 in x


True

-8 in x


False

x.pop()


7

Lists as Stacks (LIFO)

l = list(range(5))
l


[0, 1, 2, 3, 4]

l.pop()


4

l.pop()



3

l.pop()



2

l.pop()



1

l.pop()


0

l.pop()



    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

    IndexError                                Traceback (most recent call last)

    <ipython-input-45-33a5ac1f2384> in <module>
    ----> 1 l.pop()
    

    IndexError: pop from empty list

Lists as Ques (FIFO)

l = list(range(5))


l.pop(0)


0

l.pop(0)


1

l.pop(0)


2

l.pop(0)


3

l.pop(0)


4

Tuples

Characteristics

  • similar to lists
  • exception: immutable

Creating Tuples

t = (1, 2, 3, 'a', 'b', 'stella')
t


(1, 2, 3, 'a', 'b', 'stella')

t = 1, 2, 3, 'a', 'b', 'stella'
t


(1, 2, 3, 'a', 'b', 'stella')

x = 1,


x


(1,)

y = 1


y


1

x == y


False

Tuple Methods

t = 'a', 'b', 'c'
t


('a', 'b', 'c')

t.count('b')


1

t.index('b')


1

t.index('s')



    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

    ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)

    <ipython-input-62-a018879dd869> in <module>
    ----> 1 t.index('s')
    

    ValueError: tuple.index(x): x not in tuple

Immutability

t


('a', 'b', 'c')

t[0] = 'A'



    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

    TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)

    <ipython-input-64-7e674cdf20e6> in <module>
    ----> 1 t[0] = 'A'
    

    TypeError: 'tuple' object does not support item assignment

Nestable

t


('a', 'b', 'c')

s = 1, 2, t
s


(1, 2, ('a', 'b', 'c'))

Note that while the tuple is immutable, if it contains any elements that are mutable we can change the elements of the mutable elements of the tuple.

s = [1,2,3]
t = 'a', s


t


('a', [1, 2, 3])

t[1][1] = 7


t


('a', [1, 7, 3])

t[0][0]


'a'

t[0][0] = 'A'



    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

    TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)

    <ipython-input-72-1bde8b33921c> in <module>
    ----> 1 t[0][0] = 'A'
    

    TypeError: 'str' object does not support item assignment

Converting between lists and tuples

t = 'a', 'b', 'c'
t


('a', 'b', 'c')

l = list(t)
l


['a', 'b', 'c']

tl = tuple(l)
tl


('a', 'b', 'c')
〈 Strings Dictionaries 〉
